oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oak Street Baptist Church: west facade and addition
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 3224 Virginia Ave Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL

Color photograph of the red brick church, showing the exterior west wall of the 1961 building and the cross-gable addition that was built in 2003 to house offices and classrooms. The main building has arched windows of blue slag glass.

Oak Street Baptist Church, organized in 1916, is significant for its involvement in the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights. The church was an important strategy center and source of activism in the Collegeville neighborhood, which was the center of the ACMHR movement in the city. Strategy meetings about participation in the Project C demonstrations as well as voter registration methods took place at the church from 1963 to 1965. In 1965, the church became home to the Collegeville Neighborhood Association, which was a significant local institution in implementing the Civil Rights Movement in Birmingham in the mid-1970s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee
Churches
